author: BatMeckley
content:
Someone in the mix channel had mused about what Serbian’s assistant’s do, and it brings me back to “The people that know how will always work for the people that know why”

Do you know the actual reasons why you feel your work doesn’t measure up yet? Hint: it’s very rarely strictly the sonics and/or mix. That Olivia Rodrigo album sounded objectively terrible, but FELT awesome. And that’s what mattered in the end.  Benny Blanco became successful with a folder full of songs at 120 bpm cause he didn’t know how to change the tempo, and stacks of kick drums because he didn’t know how to eq (he just layers a brighter kick on top if it needs more snap). When I’d ask him why he pretty much did anything it was always “I dunno, man, it just sounds cool!”. Make sure you’re attacking the work with that kind of mindset. 

When I get lost in the minutiae I try to zoom out and just be like “does this whole track feel good? Am I instinctually bobbing my head?” And if not, why?

95% of the songs that people have sent me here, the issue hasn’t been their space, or their monitoring, or whether they used a 60s or 70s guitar, or if they mixed analog or in the box. The issues almost always tend to be much less narrow in scope. Make sure you zoom out and just go “is this cool?”

author: Slow Hand
content:
Ok. One last example (since I've already gone this far). Miles Davis. 

Miles had the technical chops. He had fathomless musical depth. He could write every single note of a big band chart if he wanted to, but he (with a few early exceptions) never did this.

His recipe for music making was this: 

A) Start with a great song (chords and melody)
B) Curate a team of players with their own strong musical identities 
C) Bring them together and let them interpret the song
D) Direct them on feel and how to listen to and respond to each other

That's it. Miles' music was never about big arranging moments, or written-out parts. He started with great raw material, great players, and great prompting and then he let them roam free and play.

So that's one more way to approach it. 

There are two things that I keep coming back to in all of this: A great song and a vision. If you have those you can set your players free to surprise and astound you.

author: LAPhill
content:
By far, the most important element in realistic orchestral sound is in the programming. You need a controller where you can automate cc1 and cc11 (modulation and expression). Instruments, especially strings, are constantly changing their volumes. Particularly on entrances and phrase-ends. If you don't have a controller for this, you can draw it all in, but that gets really tedious.

If you get that figured out, I can almost guarantee that just about any library out there will get you good results. So then it's just a matter of what sound do you gravitate towards, how elaborate of a feature set do you need, etc. Legatos are overrated and I'd take no legato over a poorly programmed one any day.

If you want a full orchestra, not just strings, I'd check out some of the all-in-one offerings from Spitfire (Albion, BBC Orchestra, or Abbey Road), East West, Orchestral Tools (Inspire), or VSL (Prime). They all will have several different articulations, a decent amount of dynamic layers, and a full set of orchestral instruments. Have a listen to them and see what sounds grab you. Spitfire and Orchestral Tools have a more prominent room sound baked in, but they all do to some extent. So be aware that, whichever library you choose, there's a certain amount of "reverb" (which is actually just the hall they're recorded in) that you will never be able to turn off.

author: Slow Hand
content:
> "How are y'all thinking about which part of this waveform should fall on which side of the beat?"
I'm listening and not looking. Nudge. Listen. Nudge. Listen.

When it comes to groove or feel it's common for the ensemble to not line up perfectly or even *sound* as if they line up perfectly on transients. Quite often the band are flamming against each other in a way that is tasteful. Sometimes they're dead-on for a beat and the next moment they're doing a tight flam. 

Don't get lost solo'ing instruments. Keep the entire song section in perspective when you tweak. If you're having trouble making choices mute a few instruments, but don't solo.

Also, fader level has a massive influence on groove. Before you start editing too hard play with your fader balances and find the groove that way. Listen to how the proportion of instruments changes the groove. It may turn out you don't need to do much, if any, micro editing.

author: Slow Hand
content:
At the risk of stating the obvious, transitions can also be telegraphed through the instrumental writing too. Whether it's a drum fill, or a chord voicing that walks up/down into the next section, or tension in the melodic voices, or shortening the notes lengths (staccato, staccatissimo).

There's also idiomatic noises from the instruments. Guitars have string scrapes, headstock rakes, that cool chattering thing from tapping near the bridge with the edge of your pick. Pianos have big glisses, horns can squeal, bowed strings can sweep a fast legato scale up into the downbeat or do a large gliss.

Then there's foley. I get a *lot* of mileage from sound libraries made for film audio. Foley artists are some creative people and you can go far layering their sounds into instruments at the transitions.

Wanted to share some thoughts spurred on by a recent experience on here. So a local artist has hired me to produce two of her songs. Vibe is singer-songwriter, soul, RnB.

We tracked drums, bass, and keys live in the studio OD'd to scratch tracks we cooked up together. The scratch tracks / demos were just guitar vocal and we were really relying on the players to fill out the arrangements, but we knew more would be added down the line.

This project has got me thinking more about the importance of how you present a song to session musicians and the 'space' you ask them to fill in a production. As well as the changing dynamics project to project affected by a revolving cast of participants, more fleshed out demos, etc... I find this a really interesting topic. Curious if anyone in the group has any unique experiences or insights whether as a producer or a musician.

I've found that the more I flesh out demos with the artist beforehand the more bound and limited the session players we bring in are based off our decisions. This can make ODs more efficient, add a clearer direction, but can also remove the opportunity for the player to really add something special. Sometimes I don't want to be too suggestive b/c I want the players to have more of a blank canvas to work with.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Wow. I'm making my way slowly through this Lanois/Beato interview and am amazed by what Lanois is describing from @ 52:24 to 53:45 regarding his approach to stacking modulations and special effects.

As he describes it, he's performing and printing his modulation effects (delay, verb, vibrato, pitch shifting, etc) one generation at a time as he iterates through the song. This allows him to fine-tune and perform the modulations on each successive pass so that every moment is honed and responsive enough that it becomes a part within the music, and not just a blanket effects chain.

So if he's doing pitch-shifted delays, he'll do a pass that goes up a fifth on certain notes and then layer another pass that modulates by a different interval at a select moment instead of leaving everything on throughout the entire section. He's honing each effect in sequence. It shows a tremendous care and sensitivity to the music that he would go through and *perform* each layer with so much intention.

This feels like a revelation to me and I can't wait to practice this.

author: peterlabberton
content: Under 40 hz? If we’re taking *that* low, in my experience usually kicks benefit from sitting just slightly above that range, especially in rock—somewhere around 50-60hz. Usually they sound punchier and less flabby with just a touch of the super low lows rolled off. Basses can move around a bit more, obviously, but I also find that usually even if you have a fundamental around or below 40 hz, the first harmonic an octave above is usually what you’re actually interested in. Also it’s very song/arrangement/tempo (!) dependent! A slower tempo or less busy kick pattern or song arrangement will let you get away with loads more super sub stuff. Faster patterns will just sound like flabby mush with tons of sub.

If you want to get a kick properly, try isolating each section rather than fading. Izotope Imager is great for this.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’ve been thinking about @Joel "Roomie" Berghult‘s question re: mixing as you since he asked it. I think what Rauirí says about not knowing what we’re doing while we’re doing it is really true, so I’ve just been trying to dissect my process in my brain, away from the computer.  I think it comes down to 2 things for me. 

Here are my thoughts:


1) Choosing Sounds. 

In addition to vibe & genre & emotional intent, each instrument or sample that you pick covers a certain area of the overall picture. Knowing where that part is going to go in the overall arrangement changes how much hi end or low end or wetness (etc.) you want. It also steers performances. 

2) Actually Mixing As You Go 

Once a part is recorded, do a quick adjustment so that you hear closer to a finished product. This helps you make better choices about what else needs to be added, (or not added,) and will likely inspire the next step.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Three things come to mind: 

1) **Note length and envelope**. That's going to have a large influence on the feel. Electronic producers will spend a *lot* of time sculpting the volume envelope relative to the tempo. Trance producers have entire plugins that give them microscopic control over the pitch and volume envelopes of kick drums.

2) **Presentation and proportion**. Is it up-front or does it sink into the back? It's easy for a 4x4 to feel hackneyed or overbearing. Sometimes all you need is a gentle *pat pat pat pat* to tie things together.

A fresh or unconventional texture will open up drastically different feels. People can dance to anything if it's got a 4x4 click, so it doesn't necessarily *need* to be a kick. You can go far using samples and percussion that sit in different registers, but play the same role.

3) **Complimentary instruments**. If the kick is the "rock" then the groove is going to come from how everything else swings over that. What's the friction like between the kick and the other elements? If the kick is a "straight man", then the other elements pushing off of it are where the magic comes from.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Ooo I love this question. I'm currently on a journey with this idea that 'arranging is mixing'. There are a few things I've learned / frameworks that have been helpful to me recently.

I have noticed that in the past in my own approach to production (as well as with some clients who send me their productions to mix) the way I thought about building the track was like assembling / stacking static blocks on top of each other. This realized more as a mental construct and not fully so in practical application. Intuition still served. But this framing became problematic and I think is endemic in music created with primarily loops and samples.

I remember hearing Jon's comments on his 'temporal approach' to mixing which he wrote about on his site (I believe a link surfaced here a few months back). Some of the language Jon used was helpful to me (i.e. painting with sound). I started to think about my productions instead like film. Each second of each section of the song is a new scene unfolding. Every type of processor then becomes a way to adjust and enhance the emotion of the characters in the story. author: Slow Hand
content:
Yup! Massive was my go-to for years prior to Massive X.

The biggest change for me is that the raw oscillators sound far better. The original Massive had a lot of aliasing that could make it sound hazy and flat. Switching over to Massive X it is crystal clear and even buzzy saw waves feel warm, pure, and tactile.

It has extremely flexible modulation capabilities that I find to be very musical as well as some very comprehensive ADSHR envelopes. It also has four different keyboard tracking curves that you can assign and tweak, which is very important when fine-tuning your patch to make sure that it sounds even across the entire range of keys.

It has a lot of musical sounding filters that can inject a ton of vibe, or be completely neutral. The *noise* section is robust and very flexible. I use it a lot.

Finally, it has a great-sounding set of internal effects (delay, chorus, saturation, verb, etc) that can be placed anywhere inside of the routing diagram. It's always a bummer when the on-board effects aren't very inspiring. But NI has a strong catalog of well-designed dsp to draw on and integrate into their products, so it's turned out great.

Overall, it's a very robust and well-rounded synthesizer that also does a lot of things extremely well. It can be super clean (like Serum) but also get very dirty, which I appreciate in a synth.

The only thing I don't like is that the preset browser kind of sucks. I prefer the original Massive's browser. NI is well aware and they have been overhauling it and slowly adding new features, so I trust in time this will be made better.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think the best thing you can do when learning a synthesizer is to pick just one or two and really take the time to learn them inside and out. There's so much overlap between the feature set and if you can get very intuitive with one synth you'll go so much farther.

Back in the day I bought NI's *Komplete* bundle and it was just way too many new instruments too fast. Too many options. I never got to know any of them very well. Most synths have all of the same features that you'll want, but there's still a learning curve for every single one that you have to get over before you can be really expressive. I wish it were as easy as picking up a guitar or a horn where everything is standardized and lies in the same place. But that's part of what makes synths great: Their plasticity.

Nowadays the only synths I reach for (unless I need a very specific sound) are *Massive X*, *Razor*, and my Moog Sub 37. The first two are very different and don't share many features. I use the Moog when I don't want to be tethered to my computer. Limiting my available tools has been a net benefit for me.

I don't know that music being hard is necessarily a good thing for it's own sake. I'd rather have it be easy and lower the friction between conception and realization. A lot of tech these days enables that ease and has opened the door to more people writing and producing their records.

But a secondary side-effect that I think we can all observe - and I think this is more to your point - is that musicians are leaning into those methods and not pursuing the hard work and practice that is necessary to do things like singing well, or playing piano with more than a base level of proficiency, or orchestrating an ensemble well. The expressive unlock of being highly proficient isn't being pursued like it was in the past decades (before we had so may technological means). People are - broadly speaking - more satisfied these days to settle for records that don't push into that potential.

author: Slow Hand
content:
If you're concerned about being too suggestive to the players about their parts then strip back the demo until it contains only the most essential parts. No fancy stuff. Just chords, melody, and lyric. *Maybe* a kick drum pattern. Lead sheet style.

If the song is good then it will still be compelling. The best songs tend to be very robust and can be played a dozen different ways because they are fundamentally compelling. If the demo doesn't feel good this way then the song may need more work.

Lesser songs will depend on the arrangement or production to be compelling, or only work in a narrow band of styles. Sometimes a song can only work one way. It's okay if this is the case for your song, but then it's up to you to present the demo with the arrangement or elements that are essential to make the song compelling, and that will close off more and more of the instrumental possibilities.

So if you want to increase the chances of a session player delivering an unexpected, brilliant, idea then set them up for success with a strong song that can be interpreted many ways.

Unless you really know what you want, writing and arranging *into* OTT from the beginning seems like a mistake because it will severely distort your ability to tell what moves you're making.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Ahhh gotcha. That's a cool goal.

So it sounds like part of what you're seeking are techniques to add pitched resonance to samples that may be atonal?

Well a resonator is a great start. If you're not already into it, I'd look into the karplus-strong theorem and physical modeling synthesis. That whole field has a lot of overlap with what you're describing. It's the kind of thing you'd hear Sophie or Jimmy Edgar do with their Elektron Monomachine.

*AAS* have a whole suite of physical modeling products that function similar to *resonator*, but are third-party plugins. Doing percussion synthesis with *Chromaphone* can do a pretty convincing recreation of certain percussion tones with the added bonus of being as flexible as a synthesizer, because it is a synthesizer!

You could tune a high-feedback delay unit until it rings at the pitch you're seeking. I can elaborate if you need more explanation. Funnily, that's the entire basis for physical modeling synthesizers.

Alternately, you could layer your samples with gently-blended sine tones. That's worth a try too. I know a lot of EDM producers are into this.

author: Deleted User
content:
All of these methods suggested will yield in different results. 

Resonators are made from delay using feedback to create tones. So you may need to resample to kill sustains - or not if you want it to have lengthiness. If you are going for SOPHIE kind of sound then you'd probably keep the feedback. 

Booms (filter resonance) are similar mechanisms but less tonal unless you turn up the feedback a lot more - it will certainly be more natural sounding as opposed to comb-filtery sound. 

Layering will give more focused pitch while maintaining the integrity of the layered sample sound, you would probably have the most control this way. 

Vocoder will have inherently baked sound because of the synthesis mechanism, it can be desirable or not depending on the scenario. 

With sampler looping, you will get grainier tail - dialing in the decay is necessary if you want the sound to be percussive because it will just continue sustaining. You can create pads this way too!

author: Deleted User

it’s generally the orange if it’s something like palm muted guitars. But always listen and feel it. It can feel better to be early in certain styles but it can feel better to be late on other styles. it also depends on who else is doing what

But groove template is always there if you wanna line it up with other instruments. bounce and make the source and destination audio files the same length, make sure the markers are in the correct place then sync them up. 

I’m 90% manual editing though. Because aligning automatically can fix notes I didn’t want to fix. you can also go measure by measure to be more careful if you want to auto align with groove templates 

you want to ask yourself “is this note late or early?” before making any moves. I like nudging with keyboard so I can fine tune how far it goes. 

Nowadays I’m more committed to “the only way to make the groove feel good is to play it that way”. I hate having to edit and to be honest, nothing beats well played rhythm section… Especially because I do a lot of in between the groove stuff, 30% quantization can mess with the feel of well landed notes. author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
My current approach to this involves a couple of principles, but this is the first that comes to mind:

1. If there’s a part with bg vocals performing different lines than the lead and there’s a lot going on, I try to have a spot earlier in the song where the exactly lines those BGs are performing have a moment to shine. For example, if there’s a low energy bridge where they can be clearly understood before the big hook where they can be perceived but not understood as well in the midst of so much. 

What this does is allow the listeners brain to process what’s being said with little effort, and then later when it’s in a tornado they can still perceive what it’s saying because they recognize it as something their brain already knows, so it’s not overwhelming for their brain to understand the words of multiple vocals going at once if there are layers of lines being performed (usually syncopated) around each other.

This applies to instruments as well, but instead of intelligibility of words I focus more on cutting frequencies so everything can fit well in the big moments. If they head a synth at full power in the intro and it comes back for a final hook, you can get away with cutting a lot of meat off of it and still have it be perceived as the same synth, without muddying the mix and also creating a nice ‘bringing the song full circle’ feeling - If the track calls for that.

I typed this off the cuff based in gut instinct so not standing by this message as full proof, but this all feels right to me as I explore what I have done for tracks, without having this much thought or words to it.

One of the most helpful things to break out of the 4/8 bar loop of death is to begin your project with the audio file of a track you love the arrangement for imported . 

Mute it and set your project to its tempo (it’s just easier ) 

Now get to jamming away 

Once you’ve built the loop you adore , 
Mute it 

Listen again from top to bottom the track you love the arrangements for . 

Listen to how the different elements come in and out , where , how . 

How are the motifs evolved . Any counter melody / rythms .

Drops and breakdowns 

Make notes of it all . 
Then copy it exactly or to the degree you want with your own elements of your loop . 

Voila . You made a fully arranged track .

author: austenballard
content:
What about when _many_ tasks become easy, thereby clearing the path to do even harder things?

All the art we make now - music, film/tv, video games... all possible because lots of subordinate tasks became easier. 

I firmly subscribe to Wagner's concept of Gesamtkunstwerk (Total Artwork), my take on which is that as art forms become easier to do, they are subordinated to even greater, more total art forms

The example I like to use is a videogame. Making a AAA game needs writers, artists, composers, actors, programmers.... video games are (I think?) by far the largest form of cultural output in economic terms because they're so encompassing of so many human skills

Now that those human skills are getting easier with AI assistance, what's next? How does art, culture, entertainment become even _bigger_, what does our next great format of cultural output look like?

Went a little off-topic for this channel but I am constantly thinking about this
